title.narrative: Skills and Employment Programme in Bangladesh (SEP-B) (Sudokkho)

description.narrative: Sudokkho aims to stimulate private sector investment in training for poor people. Sudokkho targets two sectors with high growth potential and ability to absorb large numbers of poor people in skilled and semi-skilled jobs: • RMG (Readymade Garments), • Construction (of houses and buildings) including selected input supply sectors. Sudokkho aims to ensure employment of 100,000 poor people, including women and disadvantaged populations, after successful completion of training through its partnerships with privately owned training service providers (PTPs) and industry-based training (IBT) initiatives.

Sudokkho is a seven-year skills training and employment programme in Bangladesh. The Skills and Employment Programme in Bangladesh (SEP-B) Sudokkho stimulates the private sector to deliver skills training sustainably and at scale by supporting: • Private training service-providers to train skills that match industry-demand and facilitate job placement, • Private sector firms to deliver innovative training systems and provide employment. The Sudokkho project, in Bangladesh has been closed early by FCDO, with effect from 15th October 2020 (brought forward from 31st March 2021.

Sudokkho’s objective is to reduce poverty through better training and job opportunities for the poor. For this, Sudokkho contributes to a stronger and more inclusive private sector training market creating better job opportunities for the poor.

Working with the private sector, the programme will support the development of a skills-training market and incentivise market players to invest in on-the-job and off-the-job skills training. Four core principles are crucial in building a mutually beneficial relationship between private training providers and employers: [a] Fair and open competition between prospective recipients of funds, [b] Targeting of those currently excluded from government training institutes, [c] Payment for training providers based on employment outcomes, [d] A Market Development Approach, with a focus on market-based solutions.
